name: src/client/ClientCalibration.es6.js
constructor
description:
Constructor of the calibration client module.

Note that {@linkcode ClientCalibration~start} method must be
called to restore a previous calibration.

params.name: params.updateFunction
params.description:
Called whenever the calibration changed. First to complete the
start, by calling done, and then each time the calibration is
restored from the server, because this is asynchronous.

name: start
description:
Register the receive functions, and restore the calibration from
local storage, or from the server.

name: save
description: Save calibration locally, and on the server.

name: load
description:
Load calibration locally, or from the server.

The calibration is loaded from the server when no local
configuration is found. Note that loading from the server is
asynchronous. See {@linkcode ClientCalibration~updateFunction}
passed to the constructor.

name: set
description: Locally set the calibrated values.

name: get
description:
Locally get the calibrated values.

Note that {@linkcode CalibrationClient~load} method must be
called to restore a previous calibration.

unknown.tagValue:
{calibration} or the empty object {} if no calibration
is available.

name: src/client/ClientCheckin.es6.js
ClientCheckin
description:
The `Checkin` module is responsible for keeping track of the connected clients by assigning them indices.
In case that the scenario is based on predefined positions (*i.e.* a `setup`), the indices correspond to the indices of positions that can be either assigned automatically or selected by the participants.

For instance, say that the scenario requires 12 participants who sit on a grid of 3 ⨉ 4 predefined positions.
When a client connects to the server, the `Checkin` module could assign the client to a position on the grid that is not occupied yet.
The application can indicate the participant a label that is associated with the assigned position.
Similarly, if the scenario takes place in a theater with labeled seats, the `Checkin` module would allow the participants to indicate their seat by its label (*e.g.* a row and a number).
If the scenario does not require the participants to sit at particular locations, the `Checkin` module would just assign them arbitrary indices within the range of total number of users the scenario supports.

Alternatively, when configuring the module adequately, the module can assign arbitrary indices to the the participants and request that they indicate their approximate location in the performance space on a map.

The {@link ClientCheckin} module takes care of the check-in on the client side.
The {@link ClientCheckin} module calls its `done` method when the user is checked in.

The {@link ClientCheckin} module requires the SASS partial `_77-checkin.scss`.

name: constructor
description: Creates an instance of the class. Always has a view.

params.name: options.hasView
params.description: Indicates whether the module has a view or not.

params.name: options.showDialog
params.description: Indicates whether the view displays text or not.

name: start
description:
Starts the module.
Sends a request to the server and sets up listeners for the server's response.

name: reset
description:
Resets the module to default state.
Removes WebSocket and click / touch listeners.

name: restart
description:
Restarts the module.
Sends the index, label and coordinates to the server.

name: src/client/ClientControl.es6.js
ClientControl
description:
The {@link ClientControl} module takes care of the global `parameters`, `infos`, and `commands` on the client side.
If the module is instantiated with the `gui` option set to `true`, it constructs the graphical control interface.
Otherwise it simply receives the values that are emitted by the server (usually by through the `performance` module).

The {@link ClientControl} calls its `done` method:
- Immediately after having set up the controls if the GUI is disabled;
- Never if the GUI is enabled.

name: constructor
description: Creates an instance of the class.

params.name: options.gui
params.description: Indicates whether to create the graphical user interface to control the parameters or not.

emits.description: when the server sends an update.

name: events
description: Dictionary of all the parameters and commands.

name: start
description: Starts the module and requests the parameters to the server.

name: restart
description: Restarts the module and requests the parameters to the server.

name: send
description: Sends a value or command to the server.

params.name: name
params.description: Name of the parameter or command to send.

name: update
description: Updates the value of a parameter.

params.name: name
params.description: Name of the parameter to update.

name: src/client/ClientDialog.es6.js
ClientDialog
description: The {@link ClientDialog} displays a full screen dialog. It requires the participant to tap the screen to make the view disappear. The module is also used at the very beginning of a scenario to activate the Web Audio API on iOS devices (with the option `activateWebAudio`). The `ClientDialog` module calls its `done` method when the participant taps on the screen.

name: constructor
description: Creates an instance of the class. Always has a view.

params.name: options.text
params.description: Text to be displayed in the `view`.

params.name: options.activateAudio
params.description: Indicates whether the module activates the Web Audio API when the participant touches the screen (useful on iOS devices).

params.name: options.wakeLock
params.description: Indicates whether the modules activates an ever-looping 1-pixel video to prevent the device from going idle.

name: src/client/ClientFilelist.es6.js
Filelist

params.name: options.extentions

name: files
description: Array of file paths sent by the server.

name: start

Starts the module.
Sends a request to the server and listens for the answer.

emits.description: The file path list when it is received from the server.

name: src/client/ClientLoader.es6.js
ClientLoader
description:
The {@link ClientLoader} module allows for loading audio files that can be used in the scenario (for instance, by the `performance` module).
The {@link ClientLoader} module has a view that displays a loading bar indicating the progress of the loading.
The {@link ClientLoader} module calls its `done` method when all the files are loaded.

The {@link ClientLoader} module requires the SASS partial `_77-loader.scss`.

name: constructor
description: Creates an instance of the class. Always has a view.

params.name: options.asynchronous
params.description: Indicates whether to load the files asynchronously or not.

name: buffers
description: Audio buffers created from the audio files passed in the {@link ClientLoader#constructor}.

name: src/client/ClientModule.es6.js
resolvePromised
description: [resolvePromised description]

name: ClientModule
description:
The {@link ClientModule} base class is used to create a *Soundworks* module on the client side.
Each module should have a {@link ClientModule#start} and a {@link ClientModule#done} method.
The {@link ClientModule#done} method must be called when the module can hand over the control to the subsequent modules (*i.e.* when the module has done its duty, or when it may run in the background for the rest of the scenario after it finished its initialization process).
The base class optionally creates a view — a fullscreen `div` accessible through the {@link ClientModule.view} attribute — that is added to the DOM when the module is started and removed when the module calls its {@link ClientModule#done} method.
(Specifically, the `view` element is added to the `#container` DOM element.)

name: constructor
description: Creates an instance of the class.

params.name: name
params.description: Name of the module (used as the `id` and CSS class of the `view` if it exists).

params.name: createView
params.description: Indicates whether the module has and displays a `view` or not.

params.name: color
params.description: Background color of the `view` when it exists.

name: name
description: Name of the module.

name: view
description:
View of the module.
The view is a DOM element (a full screen `div`) in which the content of the module is displayed.
This element is a child of the main container `div#container`, which is the only child of the `body` element.
A module may or may not have a view, as indicated by the argument `hasView:Boolean` of the {@link ClientModule#constructor}.
When that is the case, the view is created and added to the DOM when the {@link ClientModule#start} method is called, and is removed from the DOM when the {@link ClientModule#done} method is called.

name: start
description:
Handles the logic of the module on the client side.
For instance, it takes care of the communication with the module on the server side by sending WebSocket messages and setting up WebSocket message listeners.
Additionally, if the module has a `view`, the `start` method creates the corresponding HTML element and appends it to the DOM’s main container element (`div#container`).

**Note:** the method is called automatically when necessary, you should not call it manually.

name: reset
description:
Resets the module to the state it had before calling the {@link ClientModule#start} method.

**Note:** the method is called automatically when necessary (for instance to reset the module after a server crash if the module had not called its {@link ClientModule#done} method yet), you should not call it manually.

name: restart
description:
Restarts the module.

**Note:** the method is called automatically when necessary (for instance to restart the module after a server crash if the module had already called its {@link ClientModule#done} method), you should not call it manually.

name: done
description:
Should be called when the module can hand over the control to a subsequent module (for instance at the end of the `start` method you write).
If the module has a `view`, the `done` method removes it from the DOM.

**Note:** you should not override this method.

name: setCenteredViewContent
description:
Set an arbitrary centered HTML content to the module's `view`.
The method should be called only if the module has a `view`.

params.name: htmlContent
params.description: The HTML content to append to the `view`.

name: removeCenteredViewContent
description: Removes the centered HTML content (set by {@link ClientModule#setCenteredViewContent}) from the `view`.

name: src/client/ClientOrientation.es6.js
ClientOrientation
description:
The {@link ClientOrientation} module allows for calibrating the compass by getting an angle reference.
It displays a view with an instruction text: the user is asked to tap the screen when the phone points at the desired direction for the calibration.
When that happens, the current compass value is set as the angle reference.
The {@link ClientOrientation} module calls its `done` method when the participant taps the screen.

name: constructor
description: Creates an instance of the class. Always has a view.
todo: Solve the space in default parameter problem.

params.name: options.text
params.description: the phone exactly in front of you, and touch the screen.'] Text to be displayed in the `view`.

name: angleReference
description:
Value of the `alpha` angle (as in the [`deviceOrientation` HTML5 API](http://www.w3.org/TR/orientation-event/)) when the user touches the screen while the `ClientOrientation` module is displayed.
It serves as a calibration / reference of the compass.

name: src/client/ClientPlatform.es6.js
defaultMessages
description: Messages written in the view when the device can't pass the platform check.

name: ClientPlatform
description:
The {@link ClientPlatform} checks whether the device is compatible with the technologies used in the *Soundworks* library.
(Compatible devices are running on iOS 7 or above, or on Android 4.2 or above with the Chrome browser in version 35 or above.)
If that is not the case, the module displays a blocking view and prevents the participant to go any further in the scenario.
The {@link ClientPlatform} module calls its `done` method immediately if the device passes the platform test, and never otherwise.

name: constructor
description: Creates an instance of the class. Always has a view.

params.name: options.prefix
params.description: Additional content displayed before the error message (*e.g.* `'Welcome to My Scenario!'`).

params.name: options.postfix
params.description: Additional content displayed after the error message (*e.g.* `'You can still enjoy the performance with others!'`).

params.name: options.messages
params.description: Error messages displayed when the device doesn't pass the platform check.

params.name: options.bypass
params.description: When set to `true`, the module is bypassed (calls the `done`method immediately).

- `'selected'`: the options is selected.

(For rendering the setup graphically, see {@link ClientSpace}.)

The `ClientSetup` module requires the SASS partial `sass/_77-setup.scss`.

name: src/client/ClientSurvey.es6.js
src/client/ClientSync.es6.js
ClientSync
description:
The {@link ClientSync} module takes care of the synchronization process on the client side.
It displays "Clock syncing, stand by…" until the very first synchronization process is done.
The {@link ClientSync} module calls its `done` method as soon as the client clock is in sync with the sync clock.
Then, the synchronization process keeps running in the background to resynchronize the clocks from times to times.

name: constructor
description: Creates an instance of the class. Always has a view.

name: start
description: Starts the synchronization process.

name: getLocalTime
description:
Returns the time in the local clock.
If no arguments are provided, returns the current local time (*i.e.* `audioContext.currentTime`).

params.name: syncTime
params.description: Time in the sync clock (in seconds).

return.description: Time in the local clock corresponding to `syncTime` (in seconds).

name: getSyncTime
description:
Returns the time in the sync clock.
If no arguments are provided, returns the current sync time.

params.name: localTime
params.description: Time in the local clock (in seconds).

return.description: Time in the sync clock corresponding to `localTime` (in seconds)

name: src/client/client.es6.js
init
description: The `init` method sets the client type and initializes a WebSocket connection associated with the given type.
todo: use default value for options.io in the documentation?

params.name: options
params.description: = {}] The options to initialize a client

params.name: options.io
params.description: By default, a Soundworks application has a client and a server side. For a standalone application (client side only), use `options.io = false`.

params.name: options.socketUrl
params.description: The URL of the WebSocket server.

name: start
description: Starts the module logic (*i.e.* the application).

name: serial
description:
The `serial` method returns a `ClientModule` that starts the given `...modules` in series. After starting the first module (by calling its `start` method), the next module in the series is started (with its `start` method) when the last module called its `done` method. When the last module calls `done`, the returned serial module calls its own `done` method.

**Note:** you can compound serial module sequences with parallel module combinations (*e.g.* `client.serial(module1, client.parallel(module2, module3), module4);`).
deprecated: Use the new API with the {@link start} method.

params.name: ...modules
params.description: The modules to run in serial.

name: parallel
description:
The `ClientModule` returned by the `parallel` method starts the given `...modules` in parallel (with their `start` methods), and calls its `done` method after all modules called their own `done` methods.

**Note:** you can compound parallel module combinations with serial module sequences (*e.g.* `client.parallel(module1, client.serial(module2, module3), module4);`).

**Note:** the `view` of a module is always full screen, so in the case where modules run in parallel, their `view`s are stacked on top of each other using the `z-index` CSS property.
We use the order of the `parallel` method's arguments to determine the order of the stack (*e.g.* in `client.parallel(module1, module2, module3)`, the `view` of `module1` is displayed on top of the `view` of `module2`, which is displayed on top of the `view` of `module3`).
deprecated: Use the new API with the {@link start} method.

params.name: modules
params.description: The modules to run in parallel.

name: send
description:
Sends a WebSocket message to the server.

**Note:** on the server side, the server receives the message with the command {@link ServerClient#receive}.

params.name: msg
params.description: Name of the message to send.

params.name: args
params.description: Arguments of the message (as many as needed, of any type).

name: receive
description:
Executes a callback function when it receives a WebSocket message from the server.

**Note:** on the server side, the server sends the message with the command {@link server.send}`.

params.name: callback
params.description: Callback function executed when the message is received.

name: removeListener
description: [removeListener description]

name: client
description: The `client` object contains the basic methods of the client. For instance, the object initializes the client type with `init` and establishes WebSocket communications with the server through the methods `send` and `receive`. Additionally, it starts the scenario and sequences the modules using the methods `start`, `serial` and `parallel`.

name: src/server/ServerClient.es6.js
ServerClient
description:
The {@link ServerClient} module is used to keep track of each connected client and to communicate with it via WebSockets.
Each time a client of type `clientType` connects to the server, *Soundworks* creates a new instance of `ServerClient`.
An instance of the class is passed to the `connect` and `disconnect` methods of all the server side modules that are mapped to the `clientType` clients (see {@link server.map}), as well as to the `enter` and `exit` methods of any {@link ServerPerformance} class mapped to that same client type.

name: constructor
description: Creates an instance of the class.

params.name: clientType
params.description: Client type of the connected client.

params.name: socket
params.description: Socket object used to comminuate with the client.

name: type
description: Client type (specified when initializing the {@link client} object on the client side with {@link client.init}).

name: index
description: Index of the client as set by the {@link ServerCheckin} module.

name: coordinates
description: Coordinates of the client in the space, stored as an `[x, y]` array.

name: modules
description:
Used by any {@link ServerModule} to associate data to a particular client.
All the data associated with a module whose `name` is `moduleName` is accessible through the key `moduleName`.
For instance, the {@link ServerSync} module keeps track of the time offset between the client and the sync clocks in `this.modules.sync.timeOffset`.
Similarly, a {@link ServerPerformance} module could keep track of each client's status in `this.modules.myPerformanceName.status`.

name: socket
description: Socket used to communicate with the client.

name: send
description: Sends a WebSocket message to the client.

params.name: args
params.description: Arguments of the message (as many as needed, of any type).

name: sendVolatile
description: Sends a volatile WebSocket message to the client, *i.e.* a non-blocking WebSocket message.

params.name: msg
params.description: Name of the message to send.

params.name: args
params.description: Arguments of the message (as many as needed, of any type).

name: receive
description: Executes a callback function when it receives a WebSocket message from the client.

params.name: callback
params.description: Callback function executed when the message is received.

name: broadcast
description: Sends a WebSocket message to all the other clients of the same type (*i.e.* all the clients of type `this.clientType`, excluding this client).

params.name: msg
params.description: Name of the message to broadcast.

params.name: args
params.description: Arguments of the message (as many as needed, of any type).

name: src/server/ServerControl.es6.js
ServerControl
description:
The `Control` module is used to control an application through a dedicated client (that we usually call `conductor`).
The module allows for declaring `parameters`, `infos`, and `commands`, through which the `conductor` can control and monitor the state of the application:
- `parameters` are values that are changed by a client, sent to the server, and propagated to the other connected clients (*e.g.* the tempo of a musical application);
- `infos` are values that are changed by the server and propagated to the connected clients, to inform about the current state of the application (*e.g.* the number of connected `player` clients);
- `commands` are messages (without arguments) that are send from the client to the server (*e.g.* `start`, `stop` or `clear` — whatever they would mean for a given application) which does the necessary upon reception.

Optionally, the {@link ClientControl} module can automatically construct a simple interface from the list of declared controls that allows to change `parameters`, display `infos`, and send `commands` to the server.

The controls of different types are declared on the server side and propagated to the client side when a client is set up.

The {@link ServerControl} takes care of the parameters and commands on the server side.
To set up controls in a scenario, you should extend this class on the server side and declare the controls specific to that scenario with the appropriate methods.

name: constructor
description: Creates an instance of the class.

name: events
description: Dictionary of all the events.

name: addNumber
description: Adds a number parameter.

params.name: label
params.description: Label of the parameter (displayed on the control GUI on the client side).

params.name: step
params.description: Step to increase or decrease the parameter value.

params.name: clientTypes
params.description: Array of the client types to send the parameter to. If not set, the parameter is sent to all the client types.

name: addSelect
description: Adds a select parameter.

params.name: label
params.description: Label of the parameter (displayed on the control GUI on the client side).

params.name: options
params.description: Array of the different values the parameter can take.

params.name: init
params.description: Initial value of the parameter (has to be in the `options` array).

params.name: clientTypes
params.description: Array of the client types to send the parameter to. If not set, the parameter is sent to all the client types.

name: addInfo
description: Adds an info parameter.

params.name: label
params.description: Label of the parameter (displayed on the control GUI on the client side).

params.name: init
params.description: Initial value of the parameter (has to be in the `options` array).

params.name: clientTypes
params.description: Array of the client types to send the parameter to. If not set, the parameter is sent to all the client types.

name: addCommand
description: Adds a command.

params.name: label
params.description: Label of the command (displayed on the control GUI on the client side).

params.name: clientTypes
params.description: Array of the client types to send the parameter to. If not set, the parameter is sent to all the client types.

name: send
description: Sends an event to the clients.

params.name: name
params.description: Name of the event to send.

name: update
description: Updates the value of a parameter and sends it to the clients.

params.name: name
params.description: Name of the parameter to update.

name: src/server/ServerFilelist.es6.js
ServerFilelist
description: The {@link ServerFilelist} module allows to dynamically send a list of files stored on the server to the clients.

name: constructor
description: Creates an instance of the class.

name: src/server/ServerLocator.es6.js
ServerLocator
description: The {@link ServerLocator} module allows to store the coordinates of a client when the user enters an approximate location through the interfacte provided by the {@link ClientLocator}.

name: constructor
description: Creates an instance of the class.

params.name: options.setup
params.description: Setup used in the scenario, if any (cf. {@link ServerSetup}).

name: src/server/ServerModule.es6.js
ServerModule
description:
The {@link ServerModule} base class is used to create a *Soundworks* module on the server side.
Each module should have a {@link ServerModule#connect} and a {@link ServerModule#disconnect} method.
Any module mapped to the type of client `clientType` (thanks to the {@link server#map} method) would call its {@link ServerModule#connect} method when such a client connects to the server, and its {@link ServerModule#disconnect} method when such a client disconnects from the server.

name: constructor
description: Creates an instance of the class.

name: name
description: The name of the module.

name: connect
description:
Called when the `client` connects to the server.
This method should handle the logic of the module on the server side. For instance, it can take care of the communication with the client side module by setting up WebSocket message listeners and sending WebSocket messages, or it can add the client to a list to keep track of all the connected clients.

name: disconnect
description:
Called when the client `client` disconnects from the server.
This method should handle the logic when that happens. For instance, it can remove the socket message listeners, or remove the client from the list that keeps track of the connected clients.

name: src/server/ServerPerformance.es6.js
ServerPerformance
description:
The {@link ServerPerformance} base class constitutes a basis on which to build a performance on the server side.
Its particularity is to keep track of the clients who are currently in the performance with the array `this.clients`, and to have the `enter` and `exit` methods that inform the module when the client entered the performance (*i.e.* when the `performance` on the client side called its `start` method) and left it (*i.e.* when the `performance` on the client side called its `done` method, or if the client disconnected from the server).

name: constructor
description: Creates an instance of the class.

name: clients
description: Contains the list of the clients who are currently in the performance (*i.e.* who started the performance and have not exited it yet).

name: connect
description: Called when the client connects to the server.

name: disconnect
description: Called when the client disconnects from the server.

name: enter
description: Called when the client starts the performance on the client side.

params.name: client
params.description: The client that starts the performance.

name: exit
description: Called when the client exits the performance on the client side (*i.e.* when the `done` method of the client side module is called, or when the client disconnects from the server).

params.name: client
params.description: The client that exits the performance.

name: src/server/ServerPlacer.es6.js
ServerPlacer
description: The {@link ServerPlacer} module allows to store the place of a client selected by the user through the interfacte provided by the {@link ClientPlacer}.

name: constructor
description: Creates an instance of the class.

name: src/server/ServerSetup.es6.js
ServerSetup
description:
The `Setup` module contains the information about the setup of the performance space in terms of its surface (*i.e.* dimensions and outlines) and predefined positions (*e.g.* seats or labels on the floor).

For instance, say that the scenario requires 12 participants sitting on the floor on a grid of 3 ⨉ 4 positions, the `Setup` module would contain the information about the grid, including the positions' coordinates in space and their labels.
Similarly, if the scenario takes place in a theater where seats are numbered, the `Setup` module would contain the seating plan.

If the topography of the performance space does not matter for a given scenario, the `Setup` module is not needed.

The {@link ServerSetup} takes care of the setup on the server side.
In particular, the module provides helper functions that can generate a setup automatically from some parameters.

name: constructor
description: Creates and instance of the class.

name: getCoordinates
description: Returns an array with the coordinates of a predefined position of the setup.

params.name: index
params.description: Position index about which we want the coordinates.

name: getLabel
description: Returns the label of a predefined position of the setup.

params.name: index
params.description: Position index about which we want the coordinates.

name: getNumPositions
description:
Returns the total number of predefined positions (and / or labels) of the setup.

For instance, if the setup is a 4 ⨉ 5 matrix the method would return 20.

return.description: Number of predefined positions of the setup.

name: getSurface
description: Returns an object with the description of the setup.

name: generate
description: Generates a surface and / or predefined positions according to a given type of geometry (`type`) and the corresponding parameters (`params`).

params.name: type
params

ServerSync

name: src/server/index.es6.js
content:
'use strict';

module.exports = {
  server: require('./server'),
  Calibration: require('./ServerCalibration'),
  Checkin: require('./ServerCheckin'),
  Client: require('./ServerClient'),
  Control: require('./ServerControl'),
  Filelist: require('./ServerFilelist'),
  Locator: require('./ServerLocator'),
  Module: require('./ServerModule'),
  Performance: require('./ServerPerformance'),
  Placer: require('./ServerPlacer'),
  Setup: require('./ServerSetup'),
  Survey: require('./ServerSurvey'),
  Sync: require('./ServerSync')
};

name: src/server/logger.es6.js
src/server/server.es6.js
start
description: Starts the server.

params.name: publicPath
params.description: Public static directory of the Express app.

params.name: options.socketIO
options.osc
options.env
params.description: Environnement options (set by the user, depends on the scenario).

name: map
description:
Indicates that the clients of type `clientType` require the modules `...modules` on the server side.
Additionally, this method routes the connections from the corresponding URL to the corresponding view.
More specifically:
- A client connecting to the server through the root URL `http://my.server.address:port/` is considered as a `'player'` client and displays the view `player.ejs`;
- A client connecting to the server through the URL `http://my.server.address:port/clientType` is considered as a `clientType` client, and displays the view `clientType.ejs`.

params.name: clientType
params.description: Client type (as defined by the method {@link client.init} on the client side).

params.name: modules
params.description: Modules to map to that client type.

name: broadcast
description:
Sends a WebSocket message to all the clients of type `clientType`.

**Note:** on the client side, the clients receive the message with the method {@link client.receive}.

params.name: clientType
params.description: Client type (as defined by the method {@link client.init} on the client side).

params.name: msg
params.description: Name of the message to send.

params.name: args
params.description: Arguments of the message (as many as needed, of any type).

name: sendOSC
description: Sends an OSC message.

params.name: url
params.description: URL to send the OSC message to (if not specified, uses the address defined in the OSC config or in the options of the {@link server.start} method).

params.name: port
params.description: Port to send the message to (if not specified, uses the port defined in the OSC config or in the options of the {@link server.start} method).

name: receiveOSC
description:
Executes a callback function when it receives an OSC message.
The server listens to OSC messages at the address and port defined in the config or in the options of the {@link server.start} method.

params.name: callback
params.description: Callback function executed when the OSC message is received.

name: server
description:
The `server` object contains the basic methods of the server.
For instance, this object allows setting up, configuring and starting the server with the method `start` while the method `map` allows for managing the mapping between different types of clients and their required server modules.
Additionally, the method `broadcast` allows to send messages to all connected clients via WebSockets or OSC.
